segments.en: Numbered Discourses 10
12. The Ceremony of Descent
116. With Ajita

segments.pli: Atha kho ajito paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then the wanderer Ajita went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ajito paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
“Master Gotama, we have a spiritual companion called ‘The Philosopher’.

segments.pli: Tena pañcamattāni cittaṭṭhānasatāni cintitāni, yehi aññatitthiyā upāraddhāva jānanti upāraddhasmā”ti.
segments.en: He has worked out around five hundred arguments by which followers of other paths will know when they’ve been refuted.”
Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
“Mendicants, do you remember this philosopher’s points?”
“Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

segments.pli: yaṃ bhagavā bhāseyya, bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
segments.en: Let the Buddha speak and the mendicants will remember it.”

segments.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco adhammikena vādena adhammikaṃ vādaṃ abhiniggaṇhāti abhinippīḷeti, tena ca adhammikaṃ parisaṃ rañjeti.
segments.en: “Mendicants, take a certain person who rebuts and quashes unprincipled statements with unprincipled statements. This delights an unprincipled assembly,

segments.pli: Tena sā adhammikā parisā uccāsaddamahāsaddā hoti:
segments.en: who make a dreadful racket:
‘He’s a true philosopher! He’s a true philosopher!’

segments.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco adhammikena vādena dhammikaṃ vādaṃ abhiniggaṇhāti abhinippīḷeti, tena ca adhammikaṃ parisaṃ rañjeti.
segments.en: Another person rebuts and quashes principled statements with unprincipled statements. This delights an unprincipled assembly,

segments.pli: Tena sā adhammikā parisā uccāsaddamahāsaddā hoti:
segments.en: who make a dreadful racket:
‘He’s a true philosopher! He’s a true philosopher!’

segments.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco adhammikena vādena dhammikañca vādaṃ adhammikañca vādaṃ abhiniggaṇhāti abhinippīḷeti, tena ca adhammikaṃ parisaṃ rañjeti.
segments.en: Another person rebuts and quashes principled and unprincipled statements with unprincipled statements. This delights an unprincipled assembly,

segments.pli: Tena sā adhammikā parisā uccāsaddamahāsaddā hoti:
segments.en: who make a dreadful racket:
‘He’s a true philosopher! He’s a true philosopher!’

segments.pli: Adhammo ca, bhikkhave, veditabbo dhammo ca;
segments.en: Mendicants, you should know bad principles and good principles.
And you should know bad results and good results.

segments.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
segments.en: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.

segments.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, adhammo, katamo ca dhammo, katamo ca anattho, katamo ca attho?
segments.en: So what are bad principles? What are good principles? What are bad results? And what are good results?
Wrong view is a bad principle.
Right view is a good principle.

segments.pli: ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, ayaṃ anattho;
segments.en: And the many bad, unskillful qualities produced by wrong view are bad results.

segments.pli: sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, ayaṃ attho.
segments.en: And the many skillful qualities fully developed because of right view are good results.
Wrong thought is a bad principle.
Right thought is a good principle. …
Wrong speech is a bad principle.
Right speech is a good principle. …
Wrong action is a bad principle.
Right action is a good principle. …
Wrong livelihood is a bad principle.
Right livelihood is a good principle. …
Wrong effort is a bad principle.
Right effort is a good principle. …
Wrong mindfulness is a bad principle.
Right mindfulness is a good principle. …
Wrong immersion is a bad principle.
Right immersion is a good principle. …
Wrong knowledge is a bad principle.
Right knowledge is a good principle. …
Wrong freedom is a bad principle.
Right freedom is a good principle.

segments.pli: ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, ayaṃ anattho;
segments.en: And the many bad, unskillful qualities produced by wrong freedom are bad results.

segments.pli: sammāvimuttipaccayā ca aneke kusalā dhammā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti, ayaṃ attho.
segments.en: And the many skillful qualities fully developed because of right freedom are good results.
‘You should know bad principles and good principles.
And you should know bad results and good results.

segments.pli: Adhammañca viditvā dhammañca, anatthañca viditvā atthañca yathā dhammo yathā attho tathā paṭipajjitabban’ti,
segments.en: Knowing these things, your practice should follow the good principles with good results.’

segments.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
segments.en: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

sections.title: Then the wanderer Ajita went up to the Buddha,…

suttaplex.blurb: The wanderer Ajita informs the Buddha that a philosopher has proposed 500 cases for knowing that and argument has been won or lost. The Buddha asks the mendicants about these.
